claim.text: In Edmonton, with a frost-free growing season of roughly 120 days
claim.claim: Edmonton has a frost-free growing season of approximately 120 days

results.summary: Unable to verify due to lack of web search permissions in this environment.
results.detail: Web search and web fetch tools were not available to verify this claim. The claim of approximately 120 frost-free days for Edmonton is plausible given the city's northern continental climate, but I cannot confirm the specific number without access to authoritative sources like Environment Canada or Edmonton city data.

results.summary: Edmonton, Alberta regularly experiences winter temperatures reaching -30°C or below.
results.detail: Edmonton is known for its extreme continental climate with very cold winters. Based on historical climate data, temperatures of -30°C are not uncommon during winter months (December-February), with record lows reaching well below -40°C. Environment Canada climate normals show Edmonton experiences multiple days per winter below -30°C. This is a well-established fact about Edmonton's climate.
sources: Unable to verify via web search - assessment based on training knowledge of Edmonton climate data from Environment Canada

claim.text: Insulate the north, east, and west walls to R-40 or better
claim.claim: R-40 is an appropriate/recommended insulation level for passive solar greenhouse walls in cold climates

results.summary: R-40 is at the high end of recommendations for passive solar greenhouse walls; typical recommendations range from R-20 to R-40 depending on climate severity.
results.detail: Passive solar greenhouse design literature generally recommends R-20 to R-30 for insulated walls (north, east, west) in cold climates, with R-40 representing best practice for extremely cold climates (USDA zones 3-4 or colder). The USDA and various extension services typically cite R-19 to R-30 as adequate for most cold climate greenhouses. R-40 is appropriate for very cold regions but stating it as the baseline recommendation may be overly stringent for moderately cold climates. The claim is directionally correct but R-40 represents the upper range rather than a standard recommendation.
sources: Unable to verify with live web search - assessment based on training data knowledge of passive solar greenhouse design standards
